TextEquiv.Unicode: had unto the poore who are the perfect
images of God. Which kinde of mad
nes is heathenish & ertreme folly. But
forsomuch as other have already very,
largely spoke of the abuse of the church
goods, & we also have set down certain,
matters concerning the same else
where, I will for this time make an
end of speaking thereof,
I would also now intreate of the ho
ly time, which treatise is altogether
like that of the holy place, whereof we
disputed elsewhere, but that we have
also discoursed therof in the expoiiding
of the tenne commaundements. This,
onely I doe adde at this present time,
that there ought to bee no odious con
tention in the church concerning that
matter, but that in this and other such
like cases, discipline with charitie is
constantly to bee obserued. For it be
houeth us to bee mindfull of the most
pernicious contention about the kee
ping of Easter, which with much dan
ger and great detriment, much and
long time troubled the churches of the
East and West: and beware in anye
case that through contention there bee
not a gappeleft open uuto Sathan to
enter in. It were profitable in mine
opinion both in this case and in suche
like, to rememder the counsell which
S, Augustine giveth, That that which
is emoyned us, and is neither against
faith, nor good manners, is to be ac
counted indifferent, and to be obser
ved according to the societie of them
with whom we live. In the 1s. Epi
stle to Januarius,
Anto the holy ministery belongeth
also discipline and correction of the
ministers. How necessary this is, it
may bee gathered by these woordes of
our Lorde Christ, Lou are the salt of
the earth. If the salt hath lost her salt
nesse, what shall bee salted therewiths

had unto the poore who are the perfect images of God. Which kinde of mad nes is heathenish & ertreme folly. But forsomuch as other have already very, largely spoke of the abuse of the church goods, & we also have set down certain, matters concerning the same else where, I will for this time make an end of speaking thereof, I would also now intreate of the ho ly time, which treatise is altogether like that of the holy place, whereof we disputed elsewhere, but that we have also discoursed therof in the expoiiding of the tenne commaundements. This, onely I doe adde at this present time, that there ought to bee no odious con tention in the church concerning that matter, but that in this and other such like cases, discipline with charitie is constantly to bee obserued. For it be houeth us to bee mindfull of the most pernicious contention about the kee ping of Easter, which with much dan ger and great detriment, much and long time troubled the churches of the East and West: and beware in anye case that through contention there bee not a gappeleft open uuto Sathan to enter in. It were profitable in mine opinion both in this case and in suche like, to rememder the counsell which S, Augustine giveth, That that which is emoyned us, and is neither against faith, nor good manners, is to be ac counted indifferent, and to be obser ved according to the societie of them with whom we live. In the 1s. Epi stle to Januarius, Anto the holy ministery belongeth also discipline and correction of the ministers. How necessary this is, it may bee gathered by these woordes of our Lorde Christ, Lou are the salt of the earth. If the salt hath lost her salt nesse, what shall bee salted therewiths
It is good for nothing else but to bee
thrown out of the doores, et to be tro
den uuder foote of men. I know there
bee some that doe boast them selves of
certaine priviledges wherby they are
erempted from all discipline. But
they are deceived for the Lorde hath
made all the ministers of his Church
subiect unto discipline. Tho so ther
fore will bee exempted from discipline.
are not Christes ministers, Or, whoI
pray you will say that hee is free from
discipline, whom the Lord would have
altogether subiect and bounde unto its
Against the commaundement of God
there is no Popes lawe, no priviledge
of king or Emperour of force. For no
man can abrogate the decree of the
high God. And the Lord commandeth
to warne and correct eveny brother
that doth amisse : therefore would hee
have us also sharpely to admonishe
the ministers of the churches that are
negligent and go astray. Truely he
himselfe did often and very sharpely
reprove the whole order of the Priests
of the church of Hierusalem. Helie the
Lords priest is ill reported of in ye holie
Scripture for that hee brideled not his
sonnes beeing Priestes, with sharper
discipline. Wee reade howe the pro
phets of the Lord blamed very bitter
ly all the Colledges of Priests, and the
high Priests also. Eramples are to bee
founde in every place throughout the
holy history, and in the writings of the
Prophets. Pea, Saynt Paul repro
ved the most holy Apostle saint Pe
ter at Antioch in byria in the sight of
the whole Congregation, for that hee
taught not directly according to ye pre
script rule of the Gospell. And to bee
short, Christ hiself in the revelation
which was made to S. John the Apo
stle, doth very sharply admonish and
reprove the Angels, that is to say, the

It is good for nothing else but to bee thrown out of the doores, et to be tro den uuder foote of men. I know there bee some that doe boast them selves of certaine priviledges wherby they are erempted from all discipline. But they are deceived for the Lorde hath made all the ministers of his Church subiect unto discipline. Tho so ther fore will bee exempted from discipline. are not Christes ministers, Or, whoI pray you will say that hee is free from discipline, whom the Lord would have altogether subiect and bounde unto its Against the commaundement of God there is no Popes lawe, no priviledge of king or Emperour of force. For no man can abrogate the decree of the high God. And the Lord commandeth to warne and correct eveny brother that doth amisse : therefore would hee have us also sharpely to admonishe the ministers of the churches that are negligent and go astray. Truely he himselfe did often and very sharpely reprove the whole order of the Priests of the church of Hierusalem. Helie the Lords priest is ill reported of in ye holie Scripture for that hee brideled not his sonnes beeing Priestes, with sharper discipline. Wee reade howe the pro phets of the Lord blamed very bitter ly all the Colledges of Priests, and the high Priests also. Eramples are to bee founde in every place throughout the holy history, and in the writings of the Prophets. Pea, Saynt Paul repro ved the most holy Apostle saint Pe ter at Antioch in byria in the sight of the whole Congregation, for that hee taught not directly according to ye pre script rule of the Gospell. And to bee short, Christ hiself in the revelation which was made to S. John the Apo stle, doth very sharply admonish and reprove the Angels, that is to say, the
